class.proficiency: Dexterity, Intelligence, Acrobatics, Athletics, Deception, Insight, Intimidation, Investigation, Perception, Performance, Persuasion, Sleight of Hand, Stealth

trait.name: Scoundrel
trait.text:
Scoundrels are simplified rogues. They are ideal for new players who are looking for a less complexity or to create a more straightforward character without sacrificing effectiveness during play. Scoundrels are the very embodiment of cunning and guile, renowned for their mischievous tricks and underhanded dealings. Their sharp minds and silver tongues deceive with effortless charm, beguiling those around them and manipulating their adversaries to their advantage. With a love for the shadows and a disdain for fame, they are driven by wealth, adventure, or personal causes. Life on the street has honed the scoundrels into fiercely independent and cynical individuals, with a soul tempered by the harsh realities of survival. They learned to be acrobatic and agile, exploiting the weaknesses of their enemies and delivering devastating blows to their critical points with precision and speed. Wielding light weapons like daggers, they rely on speed and agility over brute force, moving with fluid grace that leaves their foes disoriented and struggling to keep up. In combat, scoundrels are the ultimate thieves and tricksters, leaving a trail of confusion in their wake. Their cunning, swiftness, and ability to strike from unexpected angles make them formidable opponents, cementing their reputation as masters of the shadows. With a carefree exterior and a quick wit, they are both dangerous and unpredictable, making them a valuable asset to any adventure group. But with their love for wealth and tendency to be motivated by personal gain, they can also be lucky yet unreliable allies. Scoundrels are survivors of the street, and their skills are the result of a lifetime of mischief, sly, and crafty schemes. You can't multiclass into Simplified Classes, or multiclass if you are a Simplified Class.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 204 (Homebrew)

trait.name: How to play with a Scoundrel
trait.text: The scoundrel class is a superior pick for players seeking to excel in stealth, disarming traps, unlocking doors, and employing a quick and cunning combat style. As a scoundrel, you'll enjoy a unique suite of skills, honed to razor-sharp efficiency as you level up, establishing you as a formidable stealth combatant capable of delivering potent damage and evading even the most intricate traps. At 1st level, your combat prowess is enhanced by the Sneak Attack Simplified feature. This power allows you to deal extra damage when attacking an enemy adjacent to an ally. This additional damage escalates as you progress in levels. Moreover, the Scoundrel's Agility feature facilitates your movement across the battlefield without provoking opportunity attacks, making you a master of the hit-andrun combat strategy. This class encourages strategic combat, taking advantage of positioning and allied placements to strike enemies where it hurts most. You might find yourself using the infamous "backstab" tactic often, making scoundrels excellent battlefield tacticians. As you advance in levels, your problem-solving prowess becomes increasingly prominent. The Adventurer's Aptitude and Experience features give you a bonus to ability checks and additional proficiencies, making you a versatile asset in many situations. Your inherent agility is further enhanced by the Evasion feature, ensuring your safety in dangerous situations. The Precise Striker feature significantly improves the accuracy of your attacks, reinforcing the scoundrel's reputation as a deadly and efficient combatant. In a nutshell, the scoundrel class offers a comprehensive gaming experience, granting you numerous benefits in stealth, skill proficiencies, and the ability to escape challenging situations unscathed. As a scoundrel, you'll find yourself perfectly equipped to handle everything from stealth missions to enemy mage fireballs. Pairing with complementary classes in your adventuring party can further enhance the strengths of this versatile class.

feature.name: Starting Scoundrel
feature.text:
As a 1st-level Scoundrel, you begin play with 8 + your Constitution modifier hit points.
You are proficient with the following items, in addition to any proficiencies provided by your race or background.
• Armor: Light armor • Weapons: Simple weapons, hand crossbows, longswords, rapiers, shortswords • Tools: Thieves' tools • Saving Throws: Dexterity, Intelligence • Skills: Choose four from Acrobatics, Athletics, Deception, Insight, Intimidation, Investigation, Perception, Performance, Persuasion, Sleight of Hand, and Stealth
You begin play with the following equipment, in addition to any equipment provided by your background.
• (a) a rapier or (b) a shortsword • (a) a shortbow and a quiver of 20 arrows or (b) a shortsword • (a) a burglar's pack, (b) a dungeoneer's pack, or (c) an adventurer's pack • Leather armor, two daggers, and thieves' tools
If you forgo this starting equipment, as well as the items offered by your background, you start with 4d4 × 10 gp to buy your equipment.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 204 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Sneak Attack Simplified
feature.text:
Starting at 1st level, you know how to exploit a foe's distraction to strike a vital blow. The first time on each turn that you hit a creature adjacent to an ally of yours, you deal an extra 1d8 damage. The extra damage increases as you gain levels in this class, as shown in the Sneak Attack Simplified column of the Scoundrel table.

Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 205 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Scoundrel's Agility
feature.text:
Scoundrels are known for their agility and difficulty to be hit. Starting at 1st level, your movements don't provoke opportunity attacks and your speed increases by 10 feet. Starting at 5th level, you also receive a +2 bonus to your AC.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 205 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Experience
feature.text:
Your experience grants you certain practical knowledge. At 2nd level, and again when you reach 10th and 18th level, you gain proficiency in a skill of your choice.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 205 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Adventurer's Aptitude
feature.text:
You are famous for your unmatched ability to handle complicated situations. Starting at 3rd level, you gain a +1 bonus to all ability checks that you are proficient in. This bonus increases to +2 at 6th level, +3 at 9th level, +4 at 12th level, and +5 at 15th level.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 205 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Ability Score Improvement
feature.text:
When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 206 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Scoundrel's Agility (2nd)
feature.text:
Starting at 5th level, you also receive a +2 bonus to your AC.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 205 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Precise Striker
feature.text:
Your attacks are often accurate. Starting at 5th level, you receive a +1 bonus to your attack rolls. This bonus increases to +2 at 11th level, and +3 at 17th level.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 206 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Evasion
feature.text:
Beginning at 7th level, you can nimbly dodge out of the way of certain area effects, such as a red dragon's fiery breath or an ice storm spell. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 206 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Scoundrel's Fortune
feature.text:
At 20th level, your luck always seems to be on your side when it matters the most. If an attack of yours misses a target within range, you can turn the miss into a hit. Alternatively, if you fail an ability check, you can treat the d20 roll as a 20. This feature can only be used once per short or long rest.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 206 (Homebrew)
